Context:
* The Marketing Management - Financial Services program is part of George Brown's School of Marketing.
* The program requires the completion of a one-semester work experience to graduate, which can be co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid).
* George Brown works with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities. Students apply for these opportunities and go through a competitive interview process.
* Students are encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience opportunities.
* The program provides field education opportunities with real-world problems and clients.
* Marketing students have access to membership in two marketing associations, the CMA (Canadian Marketing Association) and IAB (Interactive Advertising Bureau), included in their tuition fees.
* Benefits of CMA membership include: live and online events, professional development opportunities, tools, resources, guides for members only, networking opportunities with thousands of marketers, and access to CMA NXT.
* Benefits of IAB membership are not explicitly stated in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB) membership offers student volunteer opportunities, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, standardized courses, certification, custom workshops, career & postgraduate study opportunities, and preparation for careers in the financial services industry. The financial services industry includes banks, trust and loan companies, insurance companies, credit unions, securities dealers, finance and leasing companies, pension fund managers, mutual fund companies, independent insurance agents and brokers, and the growing fintech industry. Toronto is the leading Canadian financial services centre with over 210,000 people working in the sector and the second-largest North American financial hub after New York City.

Graduates of the program may wish to pursue other designations in the financial services sector, such as the Canadian Securities Course and licensing requirements which can be found on the Canadian Securities Institute website. To graduate, students need to complete 13 mandatory courses and 1 work experience term, which can be co-op, internship, simulation, consulting, or research projects. The required courses include COMP 1192 - Computer Applications for Database Marketing, FIN 4024 - Canadian Investments I, MARK 1027 - Marketing Management, MARK 2037 - Database Marketing Strategies, MARK 4005 - Applied Business Communications, MARK 4031 - Marketing Management-Financial Management Seminar Series, and BUS 4000 - Work Experience.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Marketing Management – Financial Services Program (Postgraduate) B406 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
EXTRACTED INFORMATION:

SEMESTER 2:
- CODE: BUS 4000
- COURSE NAME: Work Experience Prep Course (none specified pre-requisite)

Courses offered in Semester 2 with their codes and names are:
- FIN 4025: Canadian Investments II
- MARK 1031: Principles of Marketing Financial Services
- MARK 1109: Data Analytics & Data Mining
- MARK 2044: Principles of Marketing Research
- MARK 4012: Marketing Metrics
- MARK 4013: Customer Experience Fundamentals

Courses with codes, names, and pre-requisites for the Work Experience Term are:
- COOP 4002 / INTN 4002 / BAWT 4002: Work Experience Term (BUS 4000)

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Formulate a marketing plan that will meet the needs or goals of a business or organization.
- Develop an integrated marketing communications plan for a product, concept, good and/or service based on an identified market need or target.
- Formulate strategies for developing new and/or modified products, concepts, goods and services that respond to evolving market needs.
- Develop strategies for the efficient and effective placement/distribution of products, concepts, goods and services that respond to evolving markets.
- Evaluate the impact of using different marketing strategies for a product, concept, good and/or service, on the finances, Return on Investment (ROI) and business goals of an organization.
- Evaluate the viability of a concept, product, good and/or service in a local, national or international markets.
- Conduct market research to provide information needed to make marketing decisions.
- Communicate marketing information persuasively and accurately in oral, written, graphic and interactive media formats.
- Plan, prepare and deliver a sales presentation or pitch that addresses the needs of the client.
- Develop strategies with clients, customers, consumers and others to grow and maintain relationships.
- Develop learning and development strategies and plans to enhance professional growth in the field.
- Apply entrepreneurial strategies to identify and respond to new career opportunities that might include contract employment, and self-employment initiatives.
- Participate in and contribute to a framework of organizational policies and practices, when conducting business of the organization.
- Apply the principles of business ethics and corporate social responsibility to business decisions.
- Employ the management techniques of planning, organizing, directing and controlling.

Context:
The text provides information about a college program, including its focus on social responsibility and business decisions, marketing techniques, financial products and services, tuition fees for domestic and international students, additional costs, financial assistance, admission requirements, English proficiency requirements, and course exemptions.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
- The program focuses on social responsibility to business decisions and employs management techniques for marketing functions and activities.
- Marketing strategies are developed for financial products and services.
- Domestic tuition is $4,115.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
- International tuition is $18,253.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024.
- There are additional costs that are subject to change and do not include textbooks.
- The program is approved for OSAP funding if applicants meet eligibility criteria.
- Applicants need a college advanced diploma, bachelor's degree, or relevant work experience for admission, along with English proficiency test results or proof of English proficiency at the college level if applying based on work experience.
- Some college and university credits may qualify for course exemptions.

For financial aid inquiries, contact FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
